title: The 2009/10 British Election Study
abstractText:
The 2008-12 British Election Study will focus on four core questions:
 
  • Why do some people vote and others do not?
  • What factors explain which party a voter chooses?
  • What factors explain the outcome of the election?
  • How does the election affect public attitudes and British democracy more generally?     


A number of related research questions will also be addressed, such as investigating the impact of campaigning on the outcome of the election, evaluating the impact of political leaders on the vote, and exploring the activities of parties in mobilising voters. The study will conduct a series of national surveys of the British electorate, some of them involving interviews with electors in their homes, and others involving internet based surveys.  These will include panel surveys in which respondents are interviewed both before and after the election takes place.  In addition there will be daily internet based surveys during the campaign with the aim of identifying the impact of the campaigning on voting behaviour.  The study will also conduct a series of monthly surveys of opinion from 2008 until after the election, in order to track the impact of political and other events in the mid-term period.
